item.title: Top Border Official Praised Agent Who Shot Chicago Woman, Evidence Shows
item.description: A Border Patrol agent shot Marimar Martinez five times, claiming that she tried to run him over. Newly released videos and text messages reveal fresh details about what happened.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Illinois
item.media:description: Body camera footage from the shooting of Marimar Martinez in Chicago in October.

item.title: Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Jill Cowan

item.title: California Man Sentenced to 4 Years for Covert Work on China’s Behalf
item.description: The man, Mike Sun, corresponded with Chinese government officials, monitored the visit of Taiwan’s president to California and backed the election of a city council member, according to court documents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, who was then the president of Taiwan, came to California in 2023. During her visit, she met with Kevin McCarthy, a California Republican who was the speaker of the House at that time.

item.title: Vance Deletes Post Recognizing Armenian Genocide
item.description: President Trump has not recognized the Armenian genocide. The vice president’s office called the post an error.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kevin Lamarque
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and the second lady, Usha Vance, visited the Tsitsernakaberd Memorial Complex in Yerevan, Armenia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Prosecutors Fail to Bring Charges Against Democrats Involved in Illegal Orders Video
item.description: The rejection was a remarkable rebuke, suggesting that ordinary citizens did not believe that the lawmakers had committed any crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona and the other five Democratic lawmakers had posted a video that enraged President Trump by reminding active-duty members of the military and intelligence community of their obligation to refuse illegal orders.

item.title: ‘No Reason He Should Have Died’: Alex Pretti’s Parents Open Up
item.description: In their first sit-down interview, Michael and Susan Pretti avoided recriminations and recalled the son that Michael called “an exceptionally kind, caring man.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Pretti family photo
item.media:description: “The truth is, he was an exceptionally kind, caring man,” Michael Pretti said of his son, Alex.

item.title: Why the Guthrie Doorbell Footage Took More Than a Week to Retrieve
item.description: Video from a camera sold by Google probably sat in one of its vast data centers. Nancy Guthrie did not have a subscription that would have allowed easy access.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: F.B.I. via Associated Press
item.media:description: Images provided by the F.B.I. show surveillance footage taken at the home of Nancy Guthrie on a Nest camera.

item.title: What Doorbell Camera Video of the Nancy Guthrie Kidnapping Suspect Shows
item.description: The footage provided the first glimpse of a suspect in the kidnapping of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of the television host Savannah Guthrie who has been missing for 10 days.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: F.B.I, via Associated Press

item.title: Pentagon to Send 200 Troops to Nigeria
item.description: The troops will help train Nigerians to fight militants, but will not be involved in combat. U.S. forces have been assisting local soldiers with identifying potential terrorist targets.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. troops will be assigned to locations across Nigeria to provide training and technical expertise, a U.S. official said.

item.title: A Timeline of Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance
item.description: A look at the major developments in the case.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: The authorities in Pima County, Ariz., have repeatedly closed and reopened the crime scene at Nancy Guthrie’s house near Tucson since she was reported missing on Feb. 1.

item.title: Don Lemon Hires Federal Prosecutor Joseph H. Thompson in Minneapolis Church Protest Case
item.description: Facing charges over his role at a church protest, Mr. Lemon, a journalist, retained a veteran litigator who recently resigned from the U.S. attorney’s office in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: Journalist Don Lemon outside federal court in Los Angeles last month.

item.title: House Defeats Republican Bid to Block Votes on Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Three Republicans joined Democrats in rejecting a bid by G.O.P. leaders to continue skirting a law that requires the House to vote promptly on measures challenging President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: House Republicans had shielded their members from having to choose between supporting tariffs many of their constituents opposed and angering President Trump by voting to cancel them.

item.title: Congress Quietly Used Funding Law to Try to Rein In Trump on Spending
item.description: Dozens of measures sprinkled throughout the recently enacted spending package seek to tie the Trump administration’s hands on funding, an act of quiet bipartisan resistance to efforts to trample congressional power.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “These bills provide literally hundreds upon hundreds of specific funding levels and directives that this administration must now, by law, follow,” Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the top Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, said.

item.title: Cubans Sent to U.S. Prison at Guantánamo Are Returned to Cuba
item.description: The men were repatriated on the first deportation flight of the year, which delivered 170 Cubans to Havana.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Yamil Lage/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: José Martí International Airport in Havana. More than 50 men arrived at the airport on Monday.

item.title: Lutnick Acknowledges Traveling to Epstein’s Island
item.description: The commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, acknowledged at a Senate hearing that he and his family visited Jeffrey Epstein on his private island.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, testifying before the Senate Appropriations Committee at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Georgia Ballot Inquiry Originated With Election Denier in Trump White House
item.description: A newly unsealed affidavit showed that a criminal investigation into the 2020 election in Fulton County, Ga., relied heavily on claims about ballots that have been widely debunked.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Nick Corasaniti and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the F.B.I. seized 2020 ballots and other materials from an election center in Fulton County, Ga., late last month.

item.title: Michigan Judge Rebukes Justice Department’s Effort to Obtain Voter Data
item.description: The ruling from a Trump-appointed federal judge is the third in recent weeks to reject the administration’s demand for voters’ personal data from nearly every state.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling location in Detroit. The decisions offer an early indication of how the Justice Department’s nationwide quest to essentially establish a national voting database may be running into significant headwinds from the judiciary.

item.title: New Photos Show Masked Person on Nancy Guthrie’s Doorstep Before Her Disappearance
item.description: Savannah Guthrie said that her family believes Nancy Guthrie is still alive and urged anyone with information to contact the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Pima County Sheriff's Department, via Reuters
item.media:description: Images captured by a doorbell security camera at Nancy Guthrie’s house in Tucson, Ariz., on the morning of her disappearance.

item.title: DHS Shutdown Looms as Senate Democrats Reject White House ICE Deal
item.description: Republicans have so far spurned most of Democrats’ demands to rein in federal agents carrying out President Trump’s immigration crackdown, threatening a homeland security funding bill ahead of a Friday deadline.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats said they could not support continued funding for the Department of Homeland Security without new guardrails.

item.title: Former Palm Beach Police Chief Said Trump Told Him ‘Everyone’ Knew About Epstein in 2006
item.description: Michael Reiter, a former Palm Beach police chief, described a 2006 conversation with Donald Trump to the F.B.I. years later, according to a newly released document.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The former police chief’s account highlights the inconsistent statements President Trump has made over the years about his relationship with both Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: Ahead of Jobs Report, White House Seeks to Downplay Any Slowdown
item.description: President Trump’s top aides have argued in recent days that the economy is strong, even if new data on Wednesday show sluggish hiring.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: For the president, a dour jobs report could prove politically noxious.

item.title: Republican Cash Edge Threatens to Swamp Democrats in the Midterms
item.description: “Donald Trump has 99 problems going into the midterms,” one Democratic strategist said. “But money ain’t one.”
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Hands Over Some NATO Commands to European Allies
item.description: The move shows that European countries are taking more responsibility for conventional war planning, a change that President Trump has long pushed for.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meets with the secretary general of NATO, Mark Rutte, at the World Economic Forum in January.

item.title: Epstein Directed Aide to Obtain Hidden Video Cameras
item.description: “I’m installing them into Kleenex boxes now,” the aide replied in the 2014 email exchange.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Debra Kamin

item.title: Pride Flag Is Removed From Stonewall Monument After Trump Directive
item.description: The removal of the flag from the Manhattan monument, the symbolic heart of the gay rights movement, came after a Trump administration memo about flags at national park sites.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Jonathan Wolfe and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Cristina Matuozzi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at Stonewall National Monument on Tuesday. Jay W. Walker, center, told the crowd, “This park, regardless of its designation, belongs to us.”

item.title: Immigration Judge Says Rumeysa Ozturk, a Tufts Student, Cannot Be Deported
item.description: The student, Rumeysa Ozturk, who is from Turkey, was detained by immigration agents last year after she co-wrote a pro-Palestinian opinion article for her student newspaper.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rumeysa Ozturk was held in detention in Louisiana for 45 days until a federal judge released her on bail.

item.title: Susan Collins Runs for Re-election, in One of 2026’s Top Senate Fights
item.description: The Maine Republican is one of her party’s most vulnerable senators, and her seat is crucial to Democratic hopes of retaking control of the chamber.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins of Maine was widely expected to seek a sixth term.

item.title: Top Immigration Officials Refuse to Discuss Minnesota Shootings at Hearing
item.description: The heads of ICE and Customs and Border Protection told lawmakers that they could not comment on the killings of Renee Good and Alex Pretti because of continuing investigations.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Rodney Scott, the commissioner of Customs and Border Protection; Joseph Edlow, the director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services; and Todd Lyons, the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, testifying on Tuesday.

item.title: Many Residents in Minneapolis, Tempered by ICE Turmoil, Now Feel Empowered
item.description: Two months after federal agents began operations in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, residents say they have found strength in uniting as a community.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of people hold messages for Renee Good on sticks during a public day of memorial and mourning on Saturday in Minneapolis.

item.title: Some Advocates say Democratic Plan to Rein in ICE has No Teeth
item.description: Republicans have criticized proposed restrictions as overreach, while immigrant advocates and some former ICE officials question if such changes would be effective.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last month. Democrats in Congress have proposed a set of 10 “guardrails” to limit ICE.

item.title: Without a Border ‘Invasion,’ Texas G.O.P. Turns to an Old Enemy, Islam
item.description: Republican politicians and strategists in Texas are amping up anti-Muslim rhetoric as a way to energize Republican voters after several elections when the border was the animating force.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suburban homes sprouting up around a mosque in Plano, Texas, have become a target for Republican politicians in the state.

item.title: What Happens After Immigration Agents Shoot Someone?
item.description: Our reporter Allison McCann describes a pattern that appears in many of the 16 shooting cases by immigration agents in the interior of the United States over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Allison McCann, Christina Shaman, Joey Sendaydiego and Gabriel Blanco

item.title: Trump Administration Claims About Shootings by Federal Agents Unravel in Court
item.description: Before the killings of Renee Good and Alex Pretti, allegations against four others shot at by federal immigration agents failed to withstand scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phillip Brown was charged with a felony after ICE agents shot at his car in Washington last year.
